title: Misconceptions about falling objects

multiple-choice.question: What happens when two objects of different weights are dropped at the same time in a gravitational field?

options.label: A
options.text: The heavier object hits the ground first.

options.label: B
options.text: The lighter object hits the ground first.

options.label: C
options.text: Both objects hit the ground at the same time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the common misconception about the acceleration of objects falling towards the Earth?
What is the effect of the force of gravity on objects falling towards the Earth?
What do some people believe about the gravitational force on objects of different weights?

options.label: A
options.text: The force is greater on the heavier object.

options.label: B
options.text: The force is less on the heavier object.

options.label: C
options.text: The force is the same on both objects.

options.label: D
options.text: The force is zero on both objects.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the weight of an object and the gravitational force acting on it?

options.label: A
options.text: The force is directly proportional to the weight.

options.label: B
options.text: The force is inversely proportional to the weight.

options.label: C
options.text: The force is independent of the weight.

options.label: D
options.text: The force is zero for all objects.

multiple-choice.question: Why do objects of different weights accelerate at the same rate in a gravitational field?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the force of gravity is greater on the heavier object.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the force of gravity is less on the heavier object.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the force of gravity is the same on both objects.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the heavier object has more inertia.

multiple-choice.question: What is inertia, and how does it affect the acceleration of objects?

options.label: A
options.text: Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist acceleration, and it affects the acceleration of objects by making it more difficult to accelerate heavier objects.

options.label: B
options.text: Inertia is the tendency of an object to accelerate, and it affects the acceleration of objects by making it easier to accelerate heavier objects.

options.label: C
options.text: Inertia is the force of gravity, and it affects the acceleration of objects by making it the same for all objects.

options.label: D
options.text: Inertia is the weight of an object, and it affects the acceleration of objects by making it greater for heavier objects.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the mass of an object and its inertia?

options.label: A
options.text: The more massive the object, the less inertia it has.

options.label: B
options.text: The more massive the object, the more inertia it has.

options.label: C
options.text: The mass of an object has no effect on its inertia.

options.label: D
options.text: The inertia of an object is independent of its mass.

multiple-choice.question: Why do objects of different weights fall at the same rate in a gravitational field, despite having different amounts of inertia?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the force of gravity is greater on the heavier object.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the force of gravity is less on the heavier object.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the force of gravity is the same on both objects, and the more massive object has more inertia.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the objects are in a vacuum.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of dropping two objects of different weights at the same time in a gravitational field, taking into account the effects of inertia and gravity?

options.label: A
options.text: The heavier object hits the ground first.

options.label: B
options.text: The lighter object hits the ground first.

options.label: C
options.text: Both objects hit the ground at the same time.

title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What is self-assembly, and how does it work?

options.label: A
options.text: A system where ordered parts are manually assembled into a structure.

options.label: B
options.text: A system where unordered parts come together in an organized structure on their own.

options.label: C
options.text: A system where parts are assembled by machines.

options.label: D
options.text: A system where parts are assembled by humans.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of self-assembly in biology?

options.label: C
options.text: The folding of proteins and DNA replication

multiple-choice.question: How do proteins self-assemble into 3-D structures?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the interaction between amino acids along the chain and the relationship between the chain and the environment.

options.label: B
options.text: Through the use of machines and manual assembly.

options.label: C
options.text: Through the use of magnets and containers.

options.label: D
options.text: Through the use of DNA and RNA.

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of viruses in terms of self-assembly?

options.label: A
options.text: They are like bicycle chains with sequences of amino acid links.

options.label: B
options.text: They are made up of a series of sub-units with specific shapes that fit together in precise ways.

options.label: C
options.text: They are like perfect spheres that can be inflated like a bubble or a balloon.

options.label: D
options.text: They are like 3-D structures made of DNA.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential advantage of using self-assembly to build structures?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be more time-consuming and prone to human errors.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be more adaptive and less reliant on fossil fuels.

options.label: C
options.text: It can only be used for small-scale applications.

options.label: D
options.text: It can only be used for biological systems.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how self-assembly is being used in engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: The construction of buildings using traditional methods.

options.label: B
options.text: The making of molecular microchips for computers where small, molecular elements form themselves into organized pathways.

options.label: C
options.text: The manufacturing of machines using manual assembly.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of DNA to make 2-D structures.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential application of self-assembly in medicine?

options.label: A
options.text: The delivery of drugs inside the body using capsules made of DNA that release them only if certain conditions are met.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of self-assembly to make surgical instruments.

options.label: C
options.text: The use of self-assembly to make medical implants.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of self-assembly to make diagnostic equipment.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential future application of self-assembly in construction?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of self-assembly to make buildings that are more rigid and less adaptable.

options.label: B
options.text: The use of self-assembly to make buildings that can adapt on their own to environment or dynamic loading.

options.label: C
options.text: The use of self-assembly to make buildings that are more prone to human errors.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of self-assembly to make buildings that are less sustainable.

multiple-choice.question: How does self-assembly work in the context of making a perfect sphere?

options.label: A
options.text: By inflating the sphere like a bubble or a balloon.

options.label: B
options.text: By creating many identical pieces that come together to make a perfect sphere through manual assembly.

options.label: C
options.text: By designing a connection between the components like magnets and dumping them into a container.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a combination of A and C.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of self-assembly on the way we design and build things?

options.label: A
options.text: It could lead to more rigid and less adaptable systems.

options.label: B
options.text: It could lead to more sustainable and adaptable systems.

options.label: C
options.text: It could lead to more manual assembly and human errors.

options.label: D
options.text: It could lead to less innovation and creativity.

title: Why do we see illusions? - Mark Changizi

multiple-choice.question: Why do we see illusions, according to the speaker's research?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our brains are too complex to render simple images.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brains are slow and try to compensate for the delay.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our brains are tricked by optic flow and blur lines.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our brains are not evolved to handle natural stimuli.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when we move forward, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Our eyes fixate like cameras and take snapshot shots.

options.label: B
options.text: Our brains create a perception of the world immediately.

options.label: C
options.text: Our perceptions are always accurate and up-to-date.

options.label: D
options.text: Our brains do not try to compensate for the delay.

multiple-choice.question: What do the blur lines in cartoons mean to our brains?

options.label: C
options.text: That the objects are far away.

options.label: D
options.text: That the objects are close by.

multiple-choice.question: How long does it take for our perception to be created, according to the speaker?
What happens if our brains did not correct for the delay in perception?

options.label: A
options.text: We would perceive the world accurately.

options.label: B
options.text: We would bump into objects or pass them by.

options.label: C
options.text: We would see illusions more frequently.

options.label: D
options.text: We would not be able to move.

multiple-choice.question: What does the brain try to do to compensate for its slowness?

options.label: A
options.text: Create a perception of the past.

options.label: B
options.text: Create a perception of the present.

options.label: C
options.text: Create a perception of the future.

options.label: D
options.text: Create a perception of a static image.

options.label: B
options.text: They bow outwards at eye level.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The way the things project is always bowed outwards.

options.label: A
options.text: Because our brains are trying to perceive the past.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brains are trying to perceive the present.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our brains are trying to perceive the future.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our brains are not trying to perceive anything.

options.label: D
